Yet another post on Bayesian analysis and the multiple testing problem

A tale of two frameworks

Bayesian
Multiple Testing
analysis
Author
Affiliation
Quang Nguyen

Regeneron Pharmaceuticals

Published

August 22, 2022

Table of contents

  • What is the multiple testing problem?
  • References

A while ago Dr. Ben Ogorek wrote a Medium/Twitter titled “Bayesians also suffer from the multiple looks bias”, which makes the case that Bayesian statisticians can’t get free lunches and skip a whole genre of very old and very common problems in statistical analysis. The post is in itself a response to another blog post from Dr. Frank Harell titled Continuous Learning from Data: No Multiplicities from Computing and Using Bayesian Posterior Probabilities as often as Desired. The response was unfortunately a bit not really clear especially for a new practicing statistician (like me!).

I quit reading at "A key difference is that, in my simulation, there is a null hypothesis and it is always true. " Bayesians don't condition on unknowns and neither do most scientists. The goal of Bayes is to uncover the hidden truth generating the data, whether null or not.

— Frank Harrell ((f2harrell?)) March 21, 2022

This post is yet another attempt at deciphering this issue at a level that is more approachable (Spoiler alert: I’m Bayesian by aspiration).

What is the multiple testing problem?

References

Gelman, Andrew. 2022. “Bayesian Inference Continues to Completely Solve the Multiple Comparisons Problem.” https://statmodeling.stat.columbia.edu/2022/08/10/bayesian-inference-continues-to-completely-solve-the-multiple-comparisons-problem/.
Ogorek, Ben. 2022. “Bayesians Also Suffer Multiple Looks Bias.” https://medium.com/@baogorek/bayesians-also-suffer-multiple-looks-bias-cd23c827edce.
